snippet: Many in the Dominican Republic favor being part of a trend of tightening immigration. But for some, it means facing some difficult choices.
abstract: Divisions emerging between Dominicans and Haitians in Barrio Cementerio neighborhood of Sabaneta, Dominican Republic, are example of how government plan that could deport hundred to thousands of people of Haitian descent is escalating tensions and fracturing relationships; plan, proposed by Pres Danilo Medina in advance of his re-election bid, enjoys wide support as it plays on fears of immigrants common in many countries and historical epochs, but some Dominicans refuse to abandon their Haitian friends and family.

byline.original: By AZAM AHMED and SANDRA E. GARCIA
byline.contributor: Joanna Berendt contributed reporting from Warsaw, Poland.

lead_paragraph: Many in the Dominican Republic favor being part of a trend of tightening immigration. But for some, it means facing some difficult choices.

headline.main: Dominican Plan to Expel Haitians Tests Close Ties
headline.print_headline: Dominican Plan to Expel Haitians Tests Close Ties
